column1: Hamidou Diallo won the dunk contest in 2019

> ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a grown man, so I‚Äôm gonna do what I wanna do,‚Äù Hill said after the Thunder‚Äôs 112-102 loss to the Spurs. ‚ÄúIf I wanna go see my family, I‚Äôm gonna go see my family. They can‚Äôt tell me I have to stay in the room 24/7. If it‚Äôs that serious then maybe we shouldn‚Äôt be playing. It‚Äôs life. No one‚Äôs gonna be able to just cancel their whole life for this game.‚Äù  > The NBA and National Basketball Players Association agreed to several new protocols. Among them, as Hill referenced, is that players and staff are required to quarantine at home or in their hotel rooms when they‚Äôre not practicing or playing games. Exceptions include outside exercise and essential activities, like grocery shopping.   > When on the road, players and staff are prohibited from leaving their hotel or having guests in their hotel rooms.  ‚ÄúWe wanna play the game,‚Äù said Hill, a 13-year NBA veteran. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what we love to do. But at the same time if we‚Äôre casting all these rules, this and that, maybe they need to reevaluate what we‚Äôre doing.‚Äù  ...  > ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt understand some of the rules as far as we can sweat 48 minutes with the guy next to us and the team next to us, but we can‚Äôt talk to him after the game,‚Äù Hill said. ‚ÄúIt makes no sense.‚Äù   ...  > ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs challenging, obviously, not being used to all the protocols and all the rules, but for me personally it‚Äôs what‚Äôs necessary,‚Äù Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm willing to do whatever it takes to get rid of this COVID thing. If it means wearing my mask on the bench the whole time then it is what it is and I gotta do it.‚Äù   > Thunder guard Hamidou Diallo downplayed the challenges of adhering to the protocols.   > ‚ÄúThe rules are set, and it‚Äôs either you follow them or you don‚Äôt,‚Äù Diallo said. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt follow them there‚Äôs gonna be consequences to that, and if you do follow them hopefully God willing we‚Äôll stay healthy and we‚Äôll keep playing the game that we love.‚Äù   ...

And Hamidou Diallo. From end of the rotation and on the verge of slipping from there to 6moy candidate this year. Hamidou has actually been quite good this year, he has been especially good the last few games with a very efficient about 23ppg the last 2-3.  That dunk champ athleticism has really paid off so far this year, he's had a huge turnaround. I heard he trained with Dinwiddie in the offseason or something.

Bazley cons: he tries to do way too much  Pay ATTENTION TO KENRICH WILLIAMS. Kenny hustle. This guy plays winning basketball. Do not snooze on this man.   Shai hoops. That fucking step back with four mins to go in the fourth was insane. Really awesome to get to the line and go 3/3 at the end of regulation  Lebron so fucking good it‚Äôs crazy. Just an unimaginable passer and just tossed our guys around. Such a scary shooter  The refs called a lot of BULLSHIT on Luguentz Dort. Hate to see it   Forgot how quick Dennis hits the jets. He adds such a layer of dynamism to the Lakers on offense   Okc needs size so bad. Cannot stop Trez, he got what he wanted. Anytime Baze was on him he was toast    Good ass job Okc. Let‚Äôs keep competing

The Pistons are one of the worst offensive teams in the NBA - so I'd say a F.  The team's only pure shooters are Wayne Ellington (a vet who needs other to get him shots) Saddiq Bey (a rookie who is still inconsistent) & Frank Jackson (a 2-way player who is shooting well form 3 for the first time in his career).  On top of that, the only offensive creators on the team are Jerami Grant (who is not yet a good passer), Hamidou Diallo (who only recently arrived in Detroit) and Josh Jackson (who is very inefficient).   On a bright side - the Pistons actually have a solid defensive team.

I'm not a Pistons fan but always root for the Pistons. I've probably watched more Pistons games this year than most people who aren't Pistons fans. I think the future looks bright. At PG rookie Killian Hayes is a question mark but a good PG is not hard to find in this league. At SG Hamidou Diallo seems like an exciting athletic player who is a good defender and explosive scorer. At SF rookie Saddiq Bey seems like a solid defender and very good 3pt shooter. At PF Jerami Grant has been playing great and looks like one of the most improved players in the NBA this year. At C rookie Isaiah Stewart provides a strong defensive presence and has a good ability to score down low

If you want to watch a young core develop over the years from being bad to good then how‚Äôs the perfect time to be a detroit pistons fan.  We‚Äôre ass this year but so far 3/4 of the rookies we‚Äôve drafted have looked solid, and it likely could‚Äôve been 4/4 if one of them didn‚Äôt get injured 7 games in.  Jerami Grant looking like the most improved player his first season as a #1 option if the NBA doesn‚Äôt randomly say ‚Äúfuck you‚Äù and give it to Julius Randle who‚Äôs basically putting up his same numbers from last year.  Hamidou Diallo is likely to breakout here after putting up 19 last game on a minutes restriction and doing solid today too.  Then you can see vets ball out as they try to revitalize their careers here.  Shit we lose a lot, but most our losses are within 2-3possessions. I think are win margin, which we don‚Äôt get a lot, is by like 5.5pts.  We‚Äôre not a good team right now, but we have some promise.  If you wanna watch a team that‚Äôs winning now then watch Portland or Miami. Hard as shit not to love Dame or Jimmy Butler and both teams are fun to watch even without knowing who the rest of their rosters are.
Hamidou Diallo of the Detroit Thunder.

Why would you be upset? They have been abundantly clear that they aren't trying to win right now. They are also very obviously trying to find ways to wind up with a roster than can compete for championships, rather than hope to win a playoff series.   Hamidou Diallo, while a nice player, was going to be a FA.  With SGA and Dort there, they may not have been willing to pay Diallo this summer.  Why not get something instead of nothing?  He can't shoot, and he's not a lead creator. That limits his high-end value.  Also, they have a ton of room this summer (perhaps some RFA offer sheets?) and extra picks, which means roster spots could be at a premium for them...plus, they may be players in the salary dump market again.

[Pistons youth movement is genuinely exciting](https://twitter.com/RedAlternates/status/1387929113252405248?s=20):  - They have a bonafide interior threat big who covers a crazy amount of space on defense and is showing some 3pt shooting chopps in Stewart (19yo)  - They have a sharpshooting wing with great awareness and on ball D who is showing some ability to take the ball to the hoop and use his strength to finish in Bey (22yo)  - They have a stellar passing PG with incredible vision and great on-ball and help D in Killian (19yo)  - They have a raw project with Siakim-esque upside in Sekou (20yo)  - They have an athletic, sharpshooting bench sparkplug with HoF tier hair in Frank Jackson (22yo)  - And they have two athletic, multi-tool bench wings who play hard nosed defense in Josh Jackson (24yo) and Hamidou Diallo (22yo)  That's 6 players 22 or younger who could have lasting roles in Weaver's restoration (4 of whom are more or less locks) without counting Saben Lee or our 2021 pick. For context, before the moratorium lifted last fall, the only player on the team under 22yo was Sekou. Just an insane transformation in only 6 months.

Hamidou Diallo actually has a pretty similar play style. He's a physically strong and gets to the line a lot but can't really shoot. He's just only like 60% as good as Maggette.  Jimmy Butler's scoring in Miami is sorta similar.  Maggette was a unique offensive player so I can't think of any particularly great comparisons.

The 2018 draft is making bank this year. Multiple TRUE superstars at the top, and 20+ picks of incredible long term starter caliber and rotational depth. This is gonna be a hell of a redraft to mock in 10 years.  Some of the guys who just showed FLASHES this year... Alize Johnson? Hamidou Diallo? Anfernee Simons? On top of the established talent from the draft.  What a draft...

I feel like teams are getting WAY smarter. The top-20 is usually now littered with guys who you are pretty sure are going to have an impact (aside from stupid talented 18 year old freaks like Mo Bamba).  Examples of this - Huerter's jump in 2018 (long and elite shooter), Cam Johnson, Desmond Bane jumping to the 1st round, Herro's jump, Clarke's jump, etc. I feel like teams are really emphasizing skill and NBA-readiness more than ever before.  Guys like Bol Bol, Nassir Little, Darius Bazley, Kevin Knox, KPorter (he panned out), Hamidou Diallo, etc. all saw big drops in their draft stock from where they were projected by general media  I think we see some guys like Corey Kispert, Kessler Edwards, Joe Wieskamp, Trey Murphy, etc. go before super "talented" guys like Keon and Kai Jones. I see Kuminga taking a big slide as well.

Agree with some of this but:  - The Thunder may have technically picked Quickley, but the Knicks told them which player to select, the trade was already agreed to - Bazley is awful. He had decent counting stats because he plays 30 minutes, but he wouldn't play 5 minutes a game on a playoff contender  - I agree that is a tough range to pick from, but if we're going to pretend Presti is a top notch GM, he needs to occasionally hit on picks in that range like the Moreys, Masais, and RC Bufords of the NBA do.  Here's the "actual" Presti picks during that time for reference:  17	OKC	Aleksej Pokusevski 34	OKC	Theo Maledon 37	OKC	Vit Krejci 23	OKC	Darius Bazley 45	OKC	Hamidou Diallo 53	OKC	Devon Hall 57	OKC	Kevin Hervey 21	OKC	Terrance Ferguson 11	OKC	Domantas Sabonis 56	OKC	Daniel Hamilton 14	OKC	Cameron Payne 48	OKC	Dakari Johnson 21	OKC	Mitch McGary 29	OKC	Josh Huestis 55	OKC	Semaj Christon

True he made some picks that looked horrible at the time and were in fact horrible (Huestis), and some picks that didn't pan out (McGary seemed like an OK pick but was awful, although not too many good players after him in that draft besides Jokic; Terrance Ferguson was a bust too at #21 but I don't know much about how he was viewed predraft).  On the other hand there were some OK picks in that span. Along with Sabonis, Hamidou Diallo was also a pretty good draft-day trade (obviously not close to the caliber of player, but pretty good for a #45 pick), and Bazley (2019) for now seems OK at #23 although he's not a great player by any means. Cam Payne looked like a huge bust for a while but is actually a decent player now (no thanks to OKC really). Quickley last year was also a fine pick (even though they gave him up) - there's not really anyone much better taken after him.  So you're right that not a stellar drafting record from '14-20, but I don't think it's that fair to call it near the "worst in the league" given the picks he had to work with - the 3 picks of 2014 + 2017 were bad for sure, but 2015 was just Cam Payne and #48, 2018 they were #53 and #57, 2019 was Bazley and 2020 was Quickley (and the #53) who are both OK given where they were picked. (There might be other draft-day trades that I'm missing)
